newsitem.title: ITALY: Italy piles on pressure to spare death row man.
newsitem.headline: Italy piles on pressure to spare death row man.

text.p: Prime Minister Romano Prodi appealed to the governor of the U.S. state of Virginia on Tuesday to spare the life of a convicted murderer whose imminent execution has shocked Italy.

The letter to Governor George Allen, released by Prodi's office, was the latest shot in a drive to secure clemency for Joseph O'Dell, 55, that has involved Pope John Paul, President Oscar Luigi Scalfaro, parliament, lawyers and rights groups.

"I am appealing to you personally to consider the possibility of suspending the execution fixed for December 18 to allow new elements announced by O'Dell's defence to be examined," Prodi wrote in his letter to Allen.
"You will understand that whatever decision you make will cause great emotion among the public in my country."
O'Dell, convicted of the rape and murder in 1985 of 44-year-old secretary Helen Schartner of Virginia Beach, Virginia, is scheduled to die by lethal injection on Wednesday.

He and his supporters say that post-trial DNA testing shows that blood stains on his clothing do not match the victim's and want the case re-opened. They say the evidence has been ruled out by judges on a legal technicality.
The newspapers La Repubblica and Il Giornale on Tuesday said they had interviewed O'Dell by telephone at the Mecklenburg Correctional Center in Boydton, Virginia.
"I am terrified. I don't deserve to die because I'm innocent," Il Giornale quoted O'Dell as saying.
He said he had asked for his sperm to be frozen in the event of his execution so his wife, Lori Urs, could have his child.
La Reppublica quoted O'Dell as saying he wanted the Pope, who has pleaded for a reprieve, to pray for him.
"It's nice all the same to know that I won't be dying alone like the other people in this death house where they go to their execution in silence," he said.
O'Dell's defence team has petitioned the U.S. Supreme Court for a stay of execution as well as seeking clemency from Allen.
The campaign, much of it conducted over the Internet, has made front page news in Italy, which is a strong supporter of the push for a worldwide abolition of capital punishment.
Virtually all reports have accepted O'Dell's protestations of innocence almost uncritically and argued that as long as there is doubt in the case he should not be executed.

Several rights groups, including the anti-death penalty organisation Hands Off Cain and Amnesty International, were planning a torchlit vigil for O'Dell outside the U.S. embassy on Rome's Via Veneto on Tuesday evening.
A spokesman at the embassy said a "good number" of Italians had telephoned or sent faxes calling for O'Dell's reprieve.
"As the O'Dell case regards solely the state of Virginia and not the federal government we are passing these on to the state authorities," the spokesman said.
O'Dell's case has not so far drawn much publicity in the United States, where 38 states have the death penalty.
Texas leads the nation with 107 executions since capital punishment was reinstated in 1976, followed by Florida with 38 and Virginia with 36.
The eighth person executed in Virginia this year, the most in any U.S. state in 1996, died by lethal injection on Monday.
Ronald Lee Hoke Sr. was convicted of raping, robbing and stabbing a woman to death in 1985.
